X.T: Adobe taps the power of negative thinking

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Adobe tries to establish a standard for raw pictures.
Photo retouching for a Dove commercial.
The title says all.

X.T: David Griffin: How photography connects us
David Griffin: How photography connects us

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The stories of some National Geographic photos.

Some examples of using Polynomial Texture Mapping to analyze objects. A spectacular example is the Antikythera Mechanism, an astronomical mechanical computer. But the most stunning is the fact that Greeks have been able to build this mechanism 200 BC.
The composite photos are quite good, this is a pity that Erik Johansson is not a good speaker.
A detailed description of a low cost book scanner.

X.T: For true panoramic images, toss this camera in the air. Seriously
X.ST: The ball-shaped Panono contains 36 2-megapixel lenses and takes a 360x360-degree image when it is thrown into the air.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A camera that you can throw in the air to shot a full panorama.

X.T: Dreamscapes (DeepDream scaled up to Operate on Multi-Hundred Megapixel Images)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A person very proud of himself is speaking about a well-known technic (HDR + stitching) and using the result with DeepDream.

X.T: The passing of time, caught in a single photo | Stephen Wilkes
The passing of time, caught in a single photo

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Creating a single photo which combines several instants of a given day at a given location.
The title says all.
The title says all.
Fake nature photos for which the photographer harms the animals.

X.T: LiShield Can Block Smartphone Cameras for Privacy's Sake

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A system to jam photos taken with a smartphone, but it should not be difficult to work around it.

X.T: Smartphone Cameras Peek Around Corners by Analyzing Patterns of Light

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all, but the quality of the extracted data is very crude.
The experiment video corresponding to the previous article.
Why JPEG is bad for compressing text.

X.T: Photo format from Google and Mozilla could leave JPEG in the dust
X.ST: Apple's got one idea for next-gen photo technology, but a rival approach based on the new AV1 video compression tech could go a step further.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another try to replace JPEG.

X.T: Photo Tech EDU Day 1: Photo Technology Overview

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very fast presentation of optics, camera settings (shutter speed, aperture, and focus), depth of field, tone reproduction…

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 2: Photo Technology Overview Continued

ARTICLE.COMMENT: … SLR, human eye, color spaces, history of color photography…

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 3: Ray Tracing, Lenses, and Mirrors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the optics of concave/convex lenses/mirrors. Given the fact that he Clement is stammering and the duration of the presentation (just one hour), I doubt people who have never seen optics before can fully understand this.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 4: Contrast, MTF, Flare, and Noise

ARTICLE.COMMENT: First, the speaker describes luminosity and the Modulation Transfer Function. Then, it speaks about flare, its causes (reflections on the lenses, sensor, and IR cut filter) and the coated lenses.
A presentation of the physics of CMOS and CCD, then some details about anti-aliasing.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 6: Digital Camera Image Processing Pipelines

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the processing done from the data retrieved from the sensor to the generated photography: amplification, analog-to-digital conversion, dark-level adjustment, white-point estimation, demosaicing, noise reduction…
This presentation dives too much in the maths of compression to be understandable by common people…

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 8: Diffraction and Interference in Imaging

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a quick reminder of the diffraction effect (Young experiment), Rom lists some criteria of resolving power. In the second half of the presentation, he speaks about reflective and transmissive gratings.

An interesting presentation of the challenges of astrophotography: compensating for earth rotation, atmosphere distortion, frame calibration… At the end, someone from Google present an alpha version of a Web service able to find out the location of a given astronomical picture.
This is the continuation of day 7: wavelets, vector quantization, lossless compression…

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 11: Document Image Analysis with Leptonica

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
After a very unclear (because there is no image or drawing!) introduction to image analysis operations (dilatation, erosion, seedfill), Dam gives some examples of their applications using Leptonicahttp://www.leptonica.org
enHTML.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 12: High Dynamic Range Image Capture

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
After some explanation about how to generate a HDR photo (estimating the response function and performing image registration), Greg performs a demo of Photospherehttp://www.anyhere.com
enHTML, speaks about JPEG-HDR, and describes how cameras could directly generate HDR images.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 14: Exposing Digital Forgeries from Inconsistencies in Lighting

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After explaining that digital image manipulation is very widespread, Hany describes some techniques to detect them and, then, he details two algorithms estimating the location of the light source.

In the first part of her presentation, Lihi explains how to compute projections to create a flat panorama from several pictures and, in particular, how to correct some distortions of elements of interest. In the second half, she describes how to "artfully" join the pictures together without trying to respect geometry.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 18: Non-destructive, Selective, Editing of Photographs

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A presentation of LightZonehttp://lightzoneproject.org
enHTML, a non-destructive photo editor using operation layers.

X.T: Photographic Technology EDU Day 19: Non-destructive, Selective, Editing of Photographs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview of inkjet printing: dye/pigmented inks, thermal/piezo heads, paper types, color space management…

X.T: Photographic Technology EDU Day 21: Visualization Via Matlab

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Richard gives some information on parsing ICC Color Profiles, ray tracing computation, and diffraction simulation.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 22: Measuring, Interpreting and Correcting Optical Aberrations

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Erik Gross explains how to measure eye aberrations, what are the visual effects of theses and how to cure them with a laser.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day23: Raw Files and Formats

ARTICLE.COMMENT: David Cardinal describes the content of raw files and how to use them. He also warns about the fact that we may not be able to read these files in 100 years because we will have not maintain the knowledge of all their dirty tricks.

X.T: PhotoGraphic Technology Day 24: Quantization, image texture, and superresolution

ARTICLE.COMMENT: First, Lence Williams explains that interpolating midpoints of the quantization levels is not the best way to reconstruct the signal, its is better to use constraint optimization. Diego Rother then discusses about texture synthesis. I am not sure to understand the link between both.

The founder of Elphelhttp://www.elphel.com
enHTML company describes how he created high-resolution and high speed cameras based on open source (e.g. Linux).

X.T: Photographic Tech EDU Day 26: Image quality testing and real-world challenges

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
The founder of Imatesthttp://www.imatest.com
enHTML lists the quality tests which are part of his software: sharpness, chromatic aberration, noise, lens flare…
Some thinking about resolution: the 70% rule for Bayer pattern, panoramic resolution…

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 28: "Capturing more Light": Pragmatic use of HDR Capture and Tonemappging

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Uwe reminds the issue of dynamics both for capture and for the support (screen or paper). Then he speaks about the problems to capture HDR shoots (camera motion, objet motion…). He finishes by proposing his "exposure mix & match" methodology.

Highton gives a good overview of the current technologies available to shoot panoramas (hardware and stitching software), shows some of his results, describes how he shot them, and gives some advice to get good results.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 30: Imaging optics for the next decade

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some good information, but Fisher tries to present too much stuff.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 31 - Color Balance: Babies, Rugs & Sunsets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some algorithms for color balancing, from the gray world to advanced computations able to handle dusk scenes.

X.T: PhotoTechEDU Day 32 - Art, Science and Reality of High Dynamic Range (HDR) Images

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After speaking about the glare issue, John McCann gives some historical data about high dynamic range in painting, analog photography, and digital photography. He finishes by showing the efficiency of the Retinex algorithm on several examples.

X.T: Blaise Aguera y Arcas: Photosynth demo
Blaise Aguera y Arcas demos Photosynth

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of Seadragon and Photosynth.

X.T: Learning 3D Models from a Single Still Image

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Ashutosh Saxena describes the algorithms he is using to build a depth map from a single image: his results are rather impressive.

X.T: Multi-view Superpixel Stereo in Man-made environments

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed description of an algorithm building a 3D model from a small set of photos taken from known positions.

X.T: Finding Paths Through the World's Photos

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of Microsoft's Photosynth.

X.T: Viewfinder: How to Seamlessly "Flickrize" Google Earth / A Collaboration between the Institute for Creative Technology and the Interactive Media Division of the School of Cinematic Arts, USC

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to find the pose of a photo in a 3D model, such as Google Earth. The tools seem rather simple to implement, but the aim here is probably more to act as a brain teaser to get some community momentum in this domain, rather than performing a technological prowess.

X.T: IM2GPS: estimating geographic information from a single image

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using the same type of algorithm than in the previous talk, James Hays tries to locate a picture by digging through 6.000.000 geotagged photos.

X.T: PhotoSketch: A Google SketchUp Plugin for Photo-Centric 3D Modeling

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo and technical presentation of a Google SketchUp plugin able to greatly simplify the 3D modelling by automatically rebuilding the geometry of the scene and the camera poses.

X.T: Google Street View: Capturing the World at Street Level

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the evolution of Google Street View technology (captors and algorithms).
Reconstructing a 3D model from thousands of Flickr images.

X.T: The Distributed Camera: Modeling the World from Online Photos

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous work: after building a model from thousand of photos, they experiment on how to build momentum for intentional photo gathering, and they start to study how to find out where and when a picture was taken.

X.T: Using Data to "Brute Force" Hard Problems in Vision and Graphics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Alyosha Efros explains how to dig in millions of photos to find something to fill a hole in a given photo, to evaluate the size of some objects, to evaluate the 3D geometry of the scene…
Using matrix computation to detect correlations in photo labels.

X.T: What Do Those Images Have In Common?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using region segmentation, graph recording region embeddings, and graph matching to automatically (i.e. with no human-provided input) detect objects common in a small set of photos.

X.T: Radioactive astronauts: images worth a thousand experiments

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The analysis of a huge 4D dataset to evaluate how cosmic particles damage DNA.

X.T: Large image databases and small codes for object recognition

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Rob Fergus describes an algorithm to find the nearest neighbours and, then, perform recognition on a very large set of images.

X.T: The LabelMe dataset and its applications to scene and object recognition

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
There are three parts in this talk:
1) creating virtual landscape by rotating , translating or going forward into fused matching images
2) a presentation of the LabelMe dataset
3) object recognition by using scene recognition.

X.T: A General Approach to Discovering, Registering, and Extracting Features from Raster Maps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A rather detailed description of the algorithms used to recognize rasterized maps, to extract the roads and names, and, then, to register these maps.

X.T: The Ansel Adams Zone System: HDR Capture and Range Compression by Chemical Processing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: John McCann describes the manipulations (dodging and burning) performed by Ansel Adams in order to fit a high dynamic range on a printed paper.

X.T: Hobbyist to Flickr Celeb: Building a Career with Social Networking (Kevin Meredith aka lomokev)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Kevin Meredith (a Lomo fan) explains how he got into photography and how he became popular on Flickr.
A description of FullView's technology and a comparison to other panoramic camera designs.

X.T: Lytro unveils radical new camera design

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Lytro created a new kind of camera which records the rays of light instead of the image they generate on a plane.
Canon Rumors' initial PowerShot G1 X review.

X.T: Les meilleurs appareils photo 2012 selon TIPA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Canon announces EOS Rebel T4i, we go hands-on with first touchscreen DSLR
X.ST: Canon has just announced their latest Rebel-series DSLR, the T4i. The new flagship Rebel combines a new sensor, Digic 5 processor, and 3-inch touchscreen LCD in a compact SLR package.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: First impressions of Canon new DLSR.

X.T: First Review: Canon EF 600 f/4L IS II

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.ST: Canon's most enthusiast-friendly APS-C SLR to date

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information on the 70D and a little feedback after having used a pre-production camera.

X.T: Dual Pixel CMOS AF -- The story of "Technology" and "Passion"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: These pseudo interviews are marketing advertisement with no real technical information.

X.T: TUTORIAL | Top 15 Most Common Questions for NIKON D7100 Camera

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic FAQ.
A test of the D7200.
Another one.
The basics.
The autofocus modes.
